prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7496
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in NGC7496

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected line in this galaxy with the SEST telescope. We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC7496. The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC7496 has a linewidth of 130km/s, so we would smooth the spectra to a 30 km/h resolution. The observed CO(1-0) line has a main beam temperature of 40 mK, equivalent to 472 mJy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at similar distances) the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=3.5 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=2.6 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and Cs(2-1)=0.9 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=3, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.3 mJy.
CORRELATOR SETUP The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band 3. Given the broad line-widths, we will average to 4 spectral channels.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects, corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxies are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extended configuration for Band 3 (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4691
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in NGC4691

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(3-2) detected line in this galaxy with the SEST telescope (no observations of CO(1-0) are available). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in both galaxies. The observed CO(3-2) line in NGC4691 has a linewidth of 50km/s, so we would smooth the spectra to a final 5km/s resolution. The CO(1-0) line intensity was calculated assuming a conversion factor of 1.02 between the intensities of CO(3-2) and CO(1-0), as seen in NGC1068. The detected CO(3-2) has a main beam temperature of 282 mK, equivaent to 13.3 Jy; and the expected flux of CO(1-0) is thus 13.6 mJy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at similar distances), the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=102.1 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=76.6 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) = 25.5 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=3, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 8.5 mJy.
CORRELATOR SETUP The spectral windows are chosen to observe HCN(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3)., maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band3.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales of ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects, corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxis are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extended configuration for Band 2, (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4593
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) on NGC4593

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0) HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy. We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in both galaxies. The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC4593 has a linewidth of 260 km/s, so we would smooth the spectra to a final 30 km/s resolution. The observed CO(1-0) line has a main beam temperature of 26 mK, equivalent to 0.6 Jy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at similar distances), the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=3 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=2 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) = 0.7 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N>2, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.3 mJy.
CORRELATOR SETUP The spectral windows are chosen to observe HCN(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band 3.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales of ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxies are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extended configuraion for Band 3 (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7213
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in NGC7213

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with the SEST telescopoe. We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NG1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC7213. The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC7213 has a linewidth of 280 km/s, so we would smooth the spectra to a final 30 km/s resolution. The observed CO(1-0) line has a main beam temperature of 60 mK, equivalent to 1.3 Jy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at a similar distances), the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=9.4 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=7.1 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) = 2.4 mJy. We aim to detec the weakest lines with a S/N=3, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.8 mJy.
CORRELATOR SETUP The spectral windows are chosen to observe HCN(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band 3.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies we aim to resolve scales of ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects, corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxies are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extended configuration for Band 3 (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4941
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in NGC4941.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) lines from the CO(3-2), detected in this galaxy with the HHT telescope (no CO(1-0) detection is available). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observen in NGC1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC4941. The detected CO line in NGC4941 has a linewidth of 50km/s, so we will smooth the spectra to a final 5km/s resolution.
The CO(1-0) line intensity was calculated assuming a conversion factor of 1.02 between CO(3-2) intensity and CO(1-0) intensity (value also obtained from NGC1068). The expected line intensity of CO(1-0) is 5.3 Jy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at similar distances), the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=40.9 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=30.7 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1)=10.2 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=3, so our desired sensitivity per point is 3.4 mJy.
CORRELATOR SETUP The spectral windows are chosen to observe HCN(1-) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band 3.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales of ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxis are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extender configuration for Band 3 (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC1672
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in NGC1672

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in the galaxy with the SEST telescope. We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC1672. The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC1672 has a linewidth of 200km/s, so we would smooth the spectral to a final 20km/h resolution. The observed CO(1-0) line has a main beam temperature of 115 mK, equivalent to 2.31 Jy. Assuming that the emission is concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068, both galaxies lie at similar distances) the expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=17.3 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=13 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) = 4.3 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=3, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 1.4 mJy.
CORRELATOR SEPTUP. The spectral windows are chosen to observe HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to cover as much as possible of the Band 3.
ARRAY CONFIGURATION To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales of ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects, corresponds to a 1" resolution. Our galaxies are expected to have source sizes not larger than 4". This is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale at the extended configuration for Band 3 (~10"), so no ACA observations are needed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Seyfert (Sy) 2 galaxies are found to have interactions with nearby galaxies more frequently than Sy1's. This increases the starbursts processes in the formers, which fuel with more gas and dust the regions close to the central engines. It might well be that the larger amounts of dust obscure the broad-line regions (BLR), leading to the optical features that characterize them in opposition to Sy1 types (as stated by the unification theories). It has been proposed that as the starbursts exhaust the gas, the obscuration of the torus decreases, while the black hole grows and the material is eventually expelled, allowing the BLR to be visible, leading to Sy1 typical spectra. We propose to test this evolutionary scenario using observations of HCN, HCO+, CS and C2H in the Band 3. These molecules have demonstrated to be very powerful tools to follow the nuclear activity and evolution.
